content:
In https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/90632 and https://github.com/rust-lang/rust/issues/59829, there were some requests to change to a sans serif body font for readability reasons.

I looked for citations on the claim that sans serif is more readable. It's a commonplace in graphic design, but not much supported by research. What studies there have been showed insignificant difference between the two.

So my default thought is to leave it alone, since change is likely to upset people and there's not a specific benefit.

_However_, I've been thinking about cross-site consistency in the Rust ecosystem lately, and I noticed crates.io, rust-lang.org, The Book, and The Reference all use sans serif fonts for body text. Being consistent with other Rust sites might be a good reason to switch.
I don't have an opinion on serif fonts, but in general I think matching mdbook where possible is a good idea :)
If it doesn't create reability issues, coherency sounds good to me.
Yeah, i would make sure we base off of research for this. Consistency is good though
I thought rustdoc already used fira sans
oh! we use fira sans for the titles and stuff, but not the text. Which is actually quite nice
Which part? The fact that we already have fira sans or the fact that we only use it for titles? :p
i like the contrast between the titles and the text but i'm not opposed to movign everything to fira sans
Maybe we should add visual marker on the titles then
(I wish sites would just use the default fonts from the browser -- especially for people who've set them to something they find more readable -- but I know that's unacceptable to designers.)
I would also like that! hm, is there any way to detect if the user has set font overrides in their browser, and avoid our custom fonts if so?

there's a similar thing in some of the accessibility docs I've read lately - that sites should allow users to set custom foreground and background colors. But really it would be better if we could delegate that to the user agent.
Considering we use symbols from unicode, that would break very badly :)
Yeah, I feel like this only works if people have actually configured their fonts - I don't think browsers have very good defaults

jsha said:

I would also like that! hm, is there any way to detect if the user has set font overrides in their browser, and avoid our custom fonts if so?

Well, I just force my own fonts no matter what the page wants.

is that an option in Firefox? I don't see it in the Chrome settings
yes, I forget the option name but it's definitely there

I kind of like how rustdoc uses serif fonts, although I also see the advantage of sans serif. But switching from serif to sans after years of serif seems like it could be jarring, both for users used to the old font and since many crates' docs will still use the old font.

jsha said:

is that an option in Firefox? I don't see it in the Chrome settings

Yup, it's an option in FF:
image.png

(I don't see it in Chrome either.)

If using / switching to a sans serif font, at least consider using a non-ambiguous font. Internet is filled with fonts rendering l and I, O and 0 the same way. (btw aac I've been called "Lago" too many times X)

Yes! I'm sad that plain strict-geometric fonts are so common these days. You might have noticed the one I'm forcing is literacy-focused -- the first picture on its page is even a demo of Il1 :upside_down:
Yeah, this is one of the reasons that I often prefer serif fonts.
Perhaps we should try out a sans font and ask on internals for feedback

After scottmcm suggestion I've also switched to forcing Andika in the browser and it feels great (thank you!). I've been also suggested Open Sans (from google, Apache 2.0 licensed) and I find it equally good

(:warning: I'm no font/UI/a11y expert => just my observation as a user)
